resources.string: Glassman and Derocha both suggest incorporating dark leafy greens, like spinach, kale and broccoli rabe, into your diet.

Eggs are an excellent source of tryptophan, a neurotransmitter that may be beneficial for anxiety symptoms.According to one study, inadequate protein intake and tryptophan — both of which are plentiful in eggs — could be associated with higher anxiety levels

Blueberries are high in vitamin C and other antioxidants, such as flavonoids, that have been studied for their ability to improve brain health and relieve anxiety.One 4-week study found that daily supplementation with wild blueberries was linked to fewer self-reported symptoms of depression in 64 adolescents
One medium-sized naval orange provides over half of the recommended dietary allowances of vitamin C for adults but also acts as an antioxidant.

Turmeric is a spice that contains curcumin — a compound studied for its role in promoting brain health and preventing anxiety disorders.Known for its high antioxidant and anti-inflammatory properties, curcumin may help to prevent damage to brain cells related to chronic inflammation and oxidative stress

Chia seeds and pumpkin seeds are all great sources of magnesium.Loading up on the mineral may help regulate emotions. One analysis found that magnesium improved quality of life, mood, and anxiety in stressed adults
